When you begin playing, you will be shown a group of nine cards, each of which will look something like this:

All cards have four attributes: count, color, shading and shape. For this card, the count is two, the color is green, the shading is dashed and the shape is oval. 

The purpose of the game is to find all the Sets available in the cards you are shown. 

A Set is any collection of three cards where for each attribute, all cards share the same version of the attribute or none of them do. 

For example, these three cards make up a Set:

As you can see, all of them share the same color (red) and the same shading (dashed), but none of them share the number of shapes on them or their shape. \n\nHowever, these three cards do not make up a set:

As you can see, all of them share the same shape (oval) and the same number of shapes on them (one) and none of them share the same color, but the first two share the same shading (full) while the third does not (empty). 

The rules are simple, but trying to find that last Set can be anything but! 

There are three game modes available: Normal, Time Attack and PowerSet. 

Normal is the simplest form of the game; you are given a group of cards with a specified number of Sets, and you try to find them. 

Time Attack is like Normal mode, except for the fact that you have a countdown timer, and you have to find all the Sets before the timer reaches zero. 

PowerSet is the most extreme of the modes; when you play you are given a special tenth card called the join, and your goal is to find the four cards in the group such that the first two make a Set with the join and the last two make a Set with the join. For those who like a bit of challenge, PowerSet mode is highly recommended. 

And that covers everything! Now go play!
